interactivity to a powerful programming language driving modern web applications. It explains how JavaScript interacts with the browser's Document Object Model (DOM), handles events, and describes the four major waves of frontend frameworks: utility libraries like jQuery, data binding frameworks like Angular, component-based frameworks like React, and modern fullstack frameworks like Next.js."}]]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":"All UI pretty much boils down to this:"}],"\n",["$","ol",null,{"className":"x:[:is(ol,ul)_&]:my-3 x:not-first:mt-6 x:list-decimal x:ms-6","children":["\n",["$","li",null,{"className":"x:my-2","children":"Draw something on the screen"}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"className":"x:my-2","children":"Listen to and react to user events (clicks, hovers, swipes, etc.) or global events (time changed, window resized, wifi disabled)"}],"\n"]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":"JavaScript was developed in response to that second requirement; </"}],["$","span",null,{"style":{"--shiki-light":"#22863A","--shiki-dark":"#85E89D"},"children":"head"}],["$","span",null,{"style":{"--shiki-light":"#24292E","--shiki-dark":"#E1E4E8"},"children":">"}]]}],"\n",["$","span",null,{"children":[["$","span",null,{"style":{"--shiki-light":"#24292E","--shiki-dark":"#E1E4E8"},"children":"  </"}],["$","span",null,{"style":{"--shiki-light":"#22863A","--shiki-dark":"#85E89D"},"children":"body"}],["$","span",null,{"style":{"--shiki-light":"#24292E","--shiki-dark":"#E1E4E8"},"children":">"}]]}],"\n",["$","span",null,{"children":[["$","span",null,{"style":{"--shiki-light":"#24292E","--shiki-dark":"#E1E4E8"},"children":"</"}],["$","span",null,{"style":{"--shiki-light":"#22863A","--shiki-dark":"#85E89D"},"children":"html"}],["$","span",null,{"style":{"--shiki-light":"#24292E","--shiki-dark":"#E1E4E8"},"children":">"}]]}]]}]]}]]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":["By default, when the browser is parsing the HTML, if it encounters a script tag, it will stop, load, parse, and run the JavaScript before it resumes parsing the HTML. This is very rarely desired—as you almost always want to display SOMETHING to the user before you start loading a script—so you’ll either see script tags included at the bottom of the body (after the main content has been parsed and displayed) or with an async attribute (e.g. ",["$","code",null,{"className":"nextra-code","dir":"ltr","children":"<script src=\"...\" async />"}],") which does the same thing."]}],"\n",["$","h3",null,{"id":"the-dom","className":"x:tracking-tight x:text-slate-900 x:dark:text-slate-100 x:font-semibold x:target:animate-[fade-in_1.5s] x:mt-8 x:text-2xl","children":["The DOM",["$","$L17",null,{"id":"the-dom"}]]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":"JavaScript is loaded alongside the webpage, and the runtime provides hooks into the browser’s in-memory model of the page: called the “document object model” or “DOM”. The DOM lets JavaScript listen for events and modify the page in response."}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":"Much like we did with HTML or CSS, we can experiment using CodeSandbox. For example, I can query for all the paragraph tags using:"}],"\n",["$","div",null,{"data-pagefind-ignore":"all","className":"nextra-code x:relative x:not-first:mt-6","children":["$undefined",["$","pre",null,{"className":"x:group x:focus-visible:nextra-focus x:overflow-x-auto x:subpixel-antialiased x:text-[.9em] x:bg-white x:dark:bg-black x:py-4 x:leading-7","children":"And I can modify, or remove, those matching elements:"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"template":"static","files":{"/index.html":"<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html lang=\"en\">\n  <head>\n    <title>Demo app</title>\n  </head>\n  <body>\n    <div>\n      Hello\n    </div>\n    <p>\n      world\n    </p>\n    <script src=\"/script.js\" />\n  </body>\n</html>","/script.js":"const paragraphs = document.querySelectorAll(\"p\")\nfor (const paragraph of paragraphs) {\n\tparagraph.remove();\n}"}}],"\n",["$","h3",null,{"id":"events","className":"x:tracking-tight x:text-slate-900 x:dark:text-slate-100 x:font-semibold x:target:animate-[fade-in_1.5s] x:mt-8 x:text-2xl","children":["Events",["$","$L17",null,{"id":"events"}]]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":"As I said before, every UI language needs a way to respond to user events. In JavaScript, this takes the form of explicit event listeners that you can attach. For example, I can add an event listener for click events:"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"template":"static","console":true,"files":{"/index.html":"<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html lang=\"en\">\n  <head>\n    <title>Demo app</title>\n  </head>\n  <body>\n    <div id=\"parent\">\n      <div id=\"child\">\n        Click me!\n      </div>\n    </div>\n    <script src=\"/script.js\" />\n  </body>\n</html>","/script.js":"function listener() {\n\tconsole.log(\"CLICKED!\")\n}\n\ndocument.querySelector(\"#child\").addEventListener(\"click\", listener);"}}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":"Because components are nested, events may occur on multiple components:"}],"\n",["$","$L19",null,{"template":"static","console":true,"files":{"/index.html":"<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html lang=\"en\">\n  <head>\n    <title>Demo app</title>\n  </head>\n  <body>\n    <div id=\"parent\">\n      <div id=\"child\">\n        Click me!\n      </div>\n    </div>\n    <script src=\"/script.js\" />\n  </body>\n</html>","/script.js":"function childListener() {\n\tconsole.log(\"CHILD CLICKED!\")\n}\n\ndocument.querySelector(\"#child\").addEventListener(\"click\", childListener);\n\nfunction parentListener() {\n\tconsole.log(\"PARENT CLICKED!\")\n}\n\ndocument.querySelector(\"#parent\").addEventListener(\"click\", parentListener);"}}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":"You may have noticed that the parent event happens AFTER the child event. by default, events bubble from child to parent up the document tree."}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":"By selecting the element in your browser’s developer tools, you can see any event handlers attached to it:"}],"\n",["$","$L16",null,{"className":"mt-6 developers got increasingly ambitious with what web applications could do; and APIs were added to enable increasingly more native experiences; specifically:"}],"\n",["$","ul",null,{"className":"x:[:is(ol,ul)_&]:my-3 x:not-first:mt-6 x:list-disc x:ms-6","children":["\n",["$","li",null,{"className":"x:my-2","children":[["$","a",null,{"href":"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest","target":"_blank","rel":"noreferrer","className":"x:focus-visible:nextra-focus x:text-primary-600 x:underline x:hover:no-underline x:decoration-from-font x:[text-underline-position:from-font]","children":["XHR",[" ",["$","svg",null,{"fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","strokeWidth":1.7,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","height":"1em","className":"x:inline x:align-baseline x:shrink-0","children":[["$","path",null,{"d":"M7 17L17 7"}],["$","path",null,{"d":"M7 7h10v10"}]]}]]]}],": enabling webpages to programmatically query the network for additional data. (These days, the ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API","target":"_blank","rel":"noreferrer","className":"x:focus-visible:nextra-focus x:text-primary-600 common.)"]}],"\n",["$","li",null,{"className":"x:my-2","children":[["$","a",null,{"href":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML5","target":"_blank","rel":"noreferrer","className":"x:focus-visible:nextra-focus HTML, adding APIs targeted at full application development such as offline, history, geolocation, file reading, image rendering, etc."]}],"\n"]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 frameworks came about in the 2000s and provided utilities to decorate static documents rendered on the server with interactivity. They general shape was “select element” and “do something to it” (at this point, you could not select elements with CSS selectors natively). Alongside that core functionality, they provided shims to simplify various browser tasks, such as requesting data from the network (something that was difficult at the time)."}],"\n",["$","div",null,{"data-pagefind-ignore":"all","className":"nextra-code x:relative x:not-first:mt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"x:px-4 x:text-xs x:text-gray-700 x:text-2xl","children":["Wave 2: Data binding",["$","$L17",null,{"id":"wave-2-data-binding"}]]}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"className":"x:not-first:mt-6 x:leading-7","children":"The second wave came about in the late 2000s / early 2010s and made it easier to bind data to HTML. Unlike the first wave, which treated the HTML as the source of truth for data, this wave assumed that JavaScript was the source of truth for data (treating JavaScript as a first-class citizen, rather than a progressive enhancement); these frameworks made it easy to store state in JavaScript, interpolate that state into their HTML, and modify that state in response to HTML events."}],"\n",["$","div",null,{"data-pagefind-ignore":"all","className":"nextra-code x:relative x:not-first:mt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"x:px-4 x:text-xs x:text-gray-700
